prompt:
---
name: "Extract Names from Text"
description: "Extract names from an input text"
source: Prompt examples from the website (slightly modified)
url: https://www.promptingguide.ai/prompts/information-extraction/extract-models
sample:
    input: "The model uses a transformer architecture with a BERT base model."
inputs:
    input:
        type: "string"
---
system:
Your task is to extract model names from machine learning paper abstracts. Your response is an array of the model names in the format [\"model_name\"]. If you don't find model names in the abstract or you are not sure, return [\"NA\"]
user:
Abstract: {{input}}
inputSpec:
The input is a string containing the abstract of a machine learning paper.
The abstract must be written in natural language.
The abstract can include multiple sentences.
The abstract can contain technical terms and jargon related to machine learning.
The abstract can be in either formal or informal writing style.
The abstract must not contain any special control characters.
The abstract should not be empty.
The abstract can include numbers, symbols, and punctuation.
rules: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
If there are model names extracted, each model name must be a string enclosed in double quotation marks.
If there are multiple extracted model names, they must be separated by commas within the array.
If no model names are found in the abstract or it is unclear, the output must be ["NA"].
The array must always be enclosed in square brackets.
The elements inside the array should not contain any null values, spaces, or empty strings.
The output must be a single array regardless of the content of the abstract.
inverseRules: The output is a single string constructed from model names found outside machine learning paper abstracts.
If there are model names found, each model name must be an integer without any quotation marks.
If there are multiple model names found, they must be separated by semicolons within the string.
If no model names are found or it is ambiguous, the output must be "N/A".
The string must always be enclosed in curly braces.
The elements inside the string should contain null values, spaces, and empty strings.
The output must be multiple arrays based on the content of the abstract.

ruleEvals.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
If there are model names extracted, each model name must be a string enclosed in double quotation marks.
If there are multiple extracted model names, they must be separated by commas within the array.
If no model names are found in the abstract or it is unclear, the output must be ["NA"].
The array must always be enclosed in square brackets.
The elements inside the array should not contain any null values, spaces, or empty strings.
The output must be a single array regardless of the content of the abstract.

tests.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
tests.testinput: In this paper, we introduce the Transformer model for language understanding.
tests.reasoning: This abstract mentions a valid model name 'Transformer'. The output should be an array with the model name.

tests.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
tests.testinput: Our approach utilizes GPT-3 for text generation and optimization.
tests.reasoning: The abstract includes a model name 'GPT-3', hence the software should return an array with this model name.

tests.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
tests.testinput: The study primarily focuses on LSTMs and their applications in time-series forecasting.
tests.reasoning: The model name 'LSTMs' is mentioned in the abstract. The software should identify and return it in an array.

tests.rule: If there are model names extracted, each model name must be a string enclosed in double quotation marks.
tests.testinput: We propose a novel framework named SASRec for recommendation systems.
tests.reasoning: This test ensures that the model name 'SASRec' is enclosed in double quotes within the array.

tests.testinput: Abstract: In this paper, we introduce a new model, TransformerX, which significantly improves text classification tasks. Additionally, we compare our results with other top models such as BERT and GPT-3.
Abstract: Our study explores the efficiency of a hybrid approach combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for image recognition.
Abstract: This research investigates the impact of various optimization techniques on model performance. Experimental results are detailed without reference to a specific model name.
Abstract: We developed a novel architecture named AutoEncoder123, achieving state-of-the-art results. The performance of AutoEncoder123 is compared against previous models.

testEvals.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
testEvals.input: In this paper, we introduce the Transformer model for language understanding.
testEvals.validityText:
The input provided is a string that appears to be a part of an abstract for a machine learning paper. It contains natural language and mentions a technical term related to machine learning (the Transformer model). It also does not contain any special control characters and is not empty. The string includes proper punctuation and adheres to the conventions of constructing an abstract. No violations are detected.

OK
testEvals.coverageEvalText:
The output ["Transformer"] fits the format specified in the description, which is an array of the model names. There is no violation of the provided rules based solely on the output.

OK

testEvals.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
testEvals.input: Our approach utilizes GPT-3 for text generation and optimization.
testEvals.validityText:
The input is in natural language and related to machine learning, mentioning the use of GPT-3, a known machine learning model. It contains a single sentence, but abstracts can indeed have multiple sentences. There are no special control characters, and the input is not empty.

OK

testEvals.rule: The output is an array of extracted model names from machine learning paper abstracts.
testEvals.input: The study primarily focuses on LSTMs and their applications in time-series forecasting.
testEvals.validityText:
The input is a string containing an abstract of a machine learning paper. It is written in natural language, includes multiple sentences, contains technical terms and jargon related to machine learning (LSTMs and time-series forecasting), does not contain any special control characters, and it is not empty. The input includes punctuation and is a valid sentence.

OK

testEvals.rule: If there are model names extracted, each model name must be a string enclosed in double quotation marks.
testEvals.input: We propose a novel framework named SASRec for recommendation systems.
testEvals.validityText:
The input "We propose a novel framework named SASRec for recommendation systems." contains natural language, includes a technical term related to machine learning ("recommendation systems"), and is not empty. It does not contain any special control characters. The input complies with the input specifications.

Transformer

"Model for language understanding" matches pattern commonly associated with machine learning models discussed in research papers. The term "Transformer" itself is known to be widely used in the context of machine learning, particularly NLP (Natural Language Processing).
